subject: RE: [junit] JUnit will not run on JDeveloper
msgSnippet: Before digging into this at all, we should ask: does this run successfully from the command line, i.e., outside of JDeveloper? One problem you ll have is you
messageBody:
Before digging into this at all, we should ask: does this run
successfully from the command line, i.e., outside of JDeveloper?

One problem you'll have is you can't run it from the command line
because there's no main() method. Maybe that's required for
Jdeveloper's test runner too. No idea.

Scott Stirling

> -----Original Message-----
> From: viet5459 [mailto:viet5459@...]
> Sent: Thursday, November 07, 2002 6:11 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] JUnit will not run on JDeveloper
>
>
> I receive the following error from JDeveloper when running the
> MoneyTester class:
>
> The target MoneyTester1.java cannot be started as a servlet, because
> the class MoneyTester1 does not extend javax.servlet.GenericServlet.
>
> The target MoneyTester1.java cannot be started as an application,
> because the class MoneyTester1 does not have a main method.
>
> Below are my classes:
>
> public class Money {
> private int fAmount;
> private String fCurrency;
> public Money(int amount, String currency) {
> fAmount= amount;
> fCurrency= currency;
> }
>
> public int amount() {
> return fAmount;
> }
>
> public String currency() {
> return fCurrency;
> }
>
> public Money add(Money add1)
> {
> Money result;
> result = new Money(add1.fAmount + this.fAmount, this.fCurrency);
> return result;
> }
>
> public boolean equals(Money compareMoney)
> {
> if ( compareMoney.currency() == this.currency() )
> {
> if ( compareMoney.amount() == this.amount() )
> {
> return true;
> }
> }
> return false;
> }
> }
>
> =====================
>
>
> import junit.framework.Test;
> import junit.framework.TestCase;
> import junit.framework.TestSuite;
> import junit.framework.Assert;
> import Money;
>
> public class MoneyTester1 extends TestCase
> {
> public MoneyTester1(String sTestName)
> {
> super(sTestName);
> }
>
>
> public void testSimpleAdd() {
> Money m12CHF= new Money(12, "CHF"); // (1)
> Money m14CHF= new Money(24, "CHF");
> Money expected= new Money(36, "CHF");
> Money result= m12CHF.add(m14CHF); // (2)
> System.out.println("done here...");
> assertTrue(expected.equals(result)); // (3)
> }
> }
>
> According to JUnit the MoneyTester1 class should run dynamically. I
> am I missing something?
